title: Quiz 14: Respiratory Nursing
topicName: NCK Paper 1 Anatomy and Physiology Questions
description: Respiratory Nursing MCQs covering COPD, asthma, pneumonia, ARDS, and pulmonary embolism.

questions.question: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with increased dyspnea, wheezing, and productive cough. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for bronchodilation and symptom relief in this patient?
questions.explanation: Albuterol is a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) and is the first-line rescue medication for acute bronchospasm.
questions.hint: This is a Short-Acting Beta Agonist (SABA) used for rescue.

questions.question: A patient with asthma experiences nocturnal cough, wheezing, and chest tightness several times per week. Which of the following medications is most appropriate for long-term control of asthma symptoms and prevention of exacerbations?
questions.explanation: Long-term control for persistent asthma usually involves an Inhaled Corticosteroid (ICS) often combined with a Long-Acting Beta Agonist (LABA).
questions.hint: Maintenance therapy usually combines a steroid and a long-acting bronchodilator.

questions.question: Which of the following clinical findings is most consistent with a diagnosis of pneumonia?

options.text: Inspiratory crackles and dullness to percussion
Clubbing of the fingers and cyanosis
Decreased breath sounds and tracheal deviation

questions.explanation: Pneumonia causes consolidation (fluid/pus in alveoli), leading to dullness on percussion and crackles (rales) on auscultation.
questions.hint: Fluid in the lungs changes the sound from resonance to dullness.

questions.question: A patient with suspected pulmonary embolism (PE) presents with sudden onset dyspnea, pleuritic chest pain, and hemoptysis. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: CT Pulmonary Angiography (CTPA) is the gold standard diagnostic test for confirming a Pulmonary Embolism.
questions.hint: This imaging test visualizes blood vessels in the lungs.

questions.question: Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for a patient experiencing an acute asthma exacerbation with severe respiratory distress and hypoxemia?

options.text: Administration of high-flow oxygen via nasal cannula
Initiation of non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)

questions.explanation: Immediate bronchodilation is the priority to reverse the airway constriction. 'DuoNeb' (SABA + Anticholinergic) is standard.
questions.hint: Address the bronchoconstriction immediately.

questions.question: A patient with chronic bronchitis presents with chronic cough, sputum production, and exertional dyspnea. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing the patient's symptoms and improving quality of life?
questions.explanation: Smoking cessation is the single most effective intervention to slow the progression of COPD.
questions.hint: This lifestyle change halts disease progression.

questions.question: A patient with cystic fibrosis (CF) presents with recurrent pulmonary exacerbations characterized by increased sputum production, cough, and fever. Which of the following treatments is most effective for addressing the underlying pathophysiology of CF and preventing disease progression?
questions.explanation: Dornase alfa thins the thick, sticky mucus characteristic of CF, helping to clear airways and reduce infections.
questions.hint: This drug acts like 'DNA scissors' to thin mucus.

questions.question: A patient with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) develops refractory hypoxemia despite maximal ventilatory support and prone positioning. Which of the following adjunctive therapies is most likely to improve oxygenation and reduce mortality in this patient?
questions.explanation: ECMO provides extracorporeal oxygenation, allowing the lungs to rest when conventional ventilation fails.
questions.hint: An external machine takes over the work of the lungs.

questions.question: Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for a patient with a tension pneumothorax?
questions.explanation: Tension pneumothorax is an immediate life threat requiring emergent needle decompression (thoracostomy) before a formal chest tube can be placed.
questions.hint: Immediate pressure release is needed before the definitive tube.

questions.question: Which of the following conditions is characterized by chronic hypoxemia, pulmonary hypertension, and right heart failure?
questions.explanation: Cor pulmonale is defined as right-sided heart failure resulting from primary lung disease or pulmonary hypertension.
questions.hint: Right-sided heart failure caused by lung disease.

questions.question: A patient with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) presents with excessive daytime sleepiness, loud snoring, and witnessed apneic episodes during sleep. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing OSA and improving symptoms?
questions.explanation: CPAP is the gold standard treatment for moderate to severe OSA, keeping the airway open via positive pressure.
questions.hint: A machine delivers air pressure to keep the throat open.

questions.question: A patient with interstitial lung disease (ILD) develops progressive dyspnea, non-productive cough, and fine inspiratory crackles on auscultation. High-resolution computed tomography (HRCT) of the chest reveals diffuse reticular opacities and traction bronchiectasis. Which of the following ILD subtypes is most likely to present with these clinical and radiographic features?
questions.explanation: The description of diffuse reticular opacities, traction bronchiectasis, and progressive symptoms is classic for the Usual Interstitial Pneumonia (UIP) pattern seen in IPF.
questions.hint: Fibrosis without a known cause.

questions.question: A patient with acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) demonstrates hypercapnia and respiratory acidosis on arterial blood gas analysis. Which of the following ventilatory strategies is most appropriate for managing the patient's respiratory failure?

options.text: Invasive mechanical ventilation with lung protective strategy

questions.explanation: NIPPV (BiPAP) is the first-line intervention for hypercapnic respiratory failure in COPD exacerbations to avoid intubation.
questions.hint: Avoid intubation if possible using a tight-fitting mask.

questions.question: Which of the following imaging modalities is most appropriate for evaluating suspected pulmonary embolism (PE) in a pregnant patient?
questions.explanation: V/Q scan is often preferred in pregnancy if CXR is normal to reduce radiation exposure to the breast tissue compared to CTPA.
questions.hint: This scan is chosen to minimize radiation risk.

questions.question: A patient with suspected community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) is empirically started on antibiotic therapy pending culture results. Which of the following antibiotic regimens provides appropriate coverage for typical bacterial pathogens commonly implicated in CAP?
questions.explanation: This combination covers the most common typical (Strep pneumo) and atypical pathogens for hospitalized CAP.
questions.hint: A cephalosporin plus a macrolide.

questions.question: A patient with suspected tuberculosis (TB) presents with cough, weight loss, night sweats, and hemoptysis. Chest X-ray reveals upper lobe infiltrates and cavitation. Which of the following diagnostic tests is most appropriate for confirming the diagnosis of pulmonary TB?

options.text: Sputum acid-fast bacilli (AFB) smear and culture

questions.explanation: Sputum culture is the gold standard for confirming active TB diagnosis. TST and IGRA show exposure/latent infection.
questions.hint: You need to grow the bacteria to confirm active disease.

questions.question: Which of the following clinical features is most characteristic of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?

options.text: Severe cough with purulent sputum production
Chest pain exacerbated by deep breathing

questions.explanation: Refractory hypoxemia (low PaO2 despite high FiO2) is the hallmark of ARDS due to significant shunting.
questions.hint: Oxygen levels stay low even when given 100% oxygen.

questions.question: A patient with chronic respiratory failure secondary to severe restrictive lung disease requires long-term oxygen therapy to maintain adequate oxygenation. Which of the following oxygen delivery devices is most appropriate for delivering continuous supplemental oxygen in this patient?
questions.explanation: For long-term home oxygen, a nasal cannula is the most practical and comfortable device.
questions.hint: The most common and comfortable device for home use.

questions.question: A patient with suspected acute exacerbation of asthma presents with severe dyspnea, accessory muscle use, and inability to speak in full sentences. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for assessing the severity of the patient's asthma exacerbation and guiding management decisions?

options.text: Clinical assessment using standardized severity scores

questions.explanation: PEFR provides an objective measure of airflow obstruction severity compared to the patient's baseline.
questions.hint: This bedside test measures how fast a patient can blow air out.

questions.question: Which of the following factors is most likely to contribute to the development of ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in critically ill patients receiving mechanical ventilation?

options.text: Use of low tidal volume ventilation

questions.explanation: The risk of VAP increases cumulatively with every day the patient remains intubated.
questions.hint: Time is the biggest risk factor.

questions.question: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) is admitted to the hospital with acute exacerbation and respiratory failure requiring mechanical ventilation. Which of the following ventilator settings is most appropriate for minimizing the risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) in this patient?

options.text: Low tidal volume and high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP)
High tidal volume and low respiratory rate
Spontaneous breathing mode with pressure support ventilation (PSV)

questions.explanation: Lung protective ventilation (Low Vt) is universal. Option A is the best fit for VILI prevention principles.
questions.hint: Smaller breaths prevent overdistension.

questions.question: Which of the following interventions is most appropriate for managing a patient with acute respiratory failure and hypercapnia due to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) exacerbation?

options.text: Administration of supplemental oxygen via non-rebreather mask
Initiation of non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV)
Placement of an indwelling arterial catheter for continuous monitoring
Titration of inhaled bronchodilators and corticosteroids

questions.explanation: NIPPV improves ventilation, blows off CO2, and reduces the need for intubation.
questions.hint: Also known as BiPAP.

questions.question: Which of the following laboratory findings is most consistent with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?
questions.explanation: LDH is a non-specific marker of tissue damage/inflammation often elevated in lung injury like ARDS.
questions.hint: A general marker of tissue damage and inflammation.

questions.question: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) presents with acute exacerbation and severe dyspnea. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals pH 7.28, PaO2 55 mmHg, PaCO2 65 mmHg, and HCO3- 30 mEq/L. Which of the following acid-base disturbances is most likely present in this patient?
questions.explanation: pH 7.28 (Acidosis) + PaCO2 65 (High/Respiratory Acid) + HCO3 30 (High/Metabolic Alkalosis compensation). The kidneys are retaining bicarb to compensate for the chronic CO2 retention.
questions.hint: High CO2 causes the acidosis, kidneys retain bicarb to help.

questions.question: Which of the following clinical manifestations is most indicative of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?

options.text: Tachypnea with hypoxemia refractory to supplemental oxygen

questions.explanation: Refractory hypoxemia is the hallmark definition.
questions.hint: Breathing fast but oxygen stays low despite treatment.
